Award.AwardTitle: Conference: Plant Ce ll Dynamics 2019; June 18-21; University Park, PA

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
There is a strong need to develop the knowledge base that will enable the rational design of improved crop species. Towards this objective, the 2019 Plant Cell Dynamics meeting, which will be held from June 18th - 21st at the Pennsylvania State University, provides a forum for the North American plant cell biology community to come together to develop a better understanding of plant cell organelle and cell dynamics. It will also provide the opportunity for plant cell biologists to develop collaborative efforts, build a larger, stronger community and exchange knowledge in the pursuit of quantitative, theory driven cell biology. One of the meeting major goals is to understand how plant cells integrate metabolism, cytoskeletal organization, and vesicle trafficking during growth and in response to environmental challenges. By encouraging and supporting attendance of trainees from underrepresented groups, the conference will broaden participation in this developing field, which employs techniques of quantitative, predictive, and theory-driven biology, and encourages multidisciplinary approaches. By encouraging and supporting attendance of trainees from underrepresented groups, the conference will broaden participation in this developing field.

The conference will include keynote talks from experts in the field of plant cell biology as well as workshops on organelle tracking, scientific reproducibility and career development. There will be opportunities for oral and poster presentations by trainees as well as participation in the workshops.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

Around 120 scientists from more than 45 labs from North America attended the Plant Cell Dynamics VIII meeting. This meeting featured two keynote presentations. Dr. Carolyn Rasmussen from University of California-Riverside provided a modeling prediction of cell division plane orientation which was used to identify new players in the process. Dr. Tetsuya Higashiyama from Nagoya University described recent breakthroughs involving molecules of sexual reproduction identified by live-cell and synthetic-chemistry approaches. The three-day sessions covered an array of topics including cell walls, cell division, signaling, trafficking, cytoskeleton, protein/RNA dynamics and organelles. Three  workshops were highlights of the meeting. In organelle tracking workshop, the participants learned different imaging processing tools to quantify the organelle movement. It?s powerful to use the most effective ways to employ combinations of quantitative imaging techniques and computational tools to gain a mechanistic understanding of plant cellular system. The data reproducibility workshop focused on practical approaches to achieving scientific reproducibility and provides actionable advice, equipping participants with tools that participants can implement in their own work. Dr. Carolyn Rasmussen led a career development workshop focused on providing early career scientists with effective strategies for developing the professional skills and relationships to foster success at each stage of their careers, while maximizing the positive impacts of their science. The program manager Dr. Richard Cyr attended the meeting and gave a presentation about funding opportunities at the National Science Foundation.

The meeting also included oral presentations from over 45 different labs. Presentations were given almost exclusively by graduate students and post-docs, providing an important training opportunity.

Broader Impacts: This award provided fellowships that increased the participation of students and underrepresented groups in a meeting entitled ?Plant Cell Dynamics?. The meeting exposed all participants to cutting edge plant cell biology and the use of quantitative image analyses and computational tools to discover mechanisms underlying cellular processes in plants.

Publications resulting from the NSF award: Not applicable

Evidence of research products and their availability: The meeting focused on the sharing of unpublished data. Therefore, the content of the oral and poster presentations were not made publicly available. The 2019 meeting website schedule and participant list have been archived at http://www.midwestplantcellbiology.org/2019program.pdf. Any PowerPoint documents from the workshops were made available to all meeting attendees.

A total of 31 early career scientists who used NSF funding in order to attend the meeting. The recipients were balanced in terms of gender and level of experience. Five of the award winners were minority students who are developing their careers in science.
